newsitem.title: SPAIN: Bank of Spain expects yearend inflation below 2.2%.
newsitem.headline: Bank of Spain expects yearend inflation below 2.2%.

text.p: Bank of Spain governor Luis Angel Rojo said on Friday he believed that Spanish inflation would end 1997 below the new target of 2.2 percent set by the government.
In response to a query on whether the consumer price index rate would remain at 2.2 percent, he said "Yes, it will be in that area and indeed it may be even a bit lower than that."
"We have reached an area where the inflation will remain which is certainly good," Rojo told reporters.
Recently the government revised down its official inflation target to 2.2 percent from 2.6 percent.
When asked about the consumer price index outlook, Rojo said inflation would likely remain stable in May.
Spanish April CPI rose at a 1.7 percent rate year-on-year.
Rojo reiterated his optimism over the high probability that Spain would join the first wave of entrants to European economic and Monetary Union.
He added that the inflation requirement would be met with relative ease.
